document_data.name: Greater Titans
document_data.mainbody:
The '''Greater Titans''', sometimes referred to simply as '''the Titans''' or the '''elder gods''', were a powerful group of [[deities]] that once dominated much of the [[plane]] of [[Arborea]], until they were overthrown by the [[Olympian pantheon]] and imprisoned in the bowels of [[Carceri]].<ref>{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|2}}

According to some they were [[greater deities]], to others they were merely [[intermediate deities]], and still others claimed they altogether weren't quite deities, being sort of [[Quasi-deity|quasi-deities]]<ref> with power comparable to the other deities that dwelled in Carceri.
document_data.Organization:
The Titans of Carceri were ruled despotically by their sibling Cronus. He ruled them with an iron fist and constantly reminded his siblings that it was only by his hand that they ever ruled Arborea. Because of his despotism, not all of the Titans were supportive of Cronus's rule,

The other Titans resented having to come to his beck-and-call, often storming off from conversations with him in a destructive huff. They spoke in private of one day revolting against Cronus and laying him low, but would bide their time until that day came. Cronus in turn was constantly paranoid of his siblings plotting against him and kept a close eye on them all.
document_data.Activities:
Much of existence for the greater titans was filled with plotting their revenge against the Olympians<ref> and searching for ways to escape their imprisonment. Sometimes they would seize upon people traveling through Carceri in hopes that they might possess some form of abilities, knowledge, or items that could aid them in their plans.

Unlike the Olympians, whenever they were slighted the Titans usually didn't send people on tasks for repentance. Instead they went straight to exacting vengeance.
document_data.Base of Operations:
Prior to their downfall the Titans all lived on the plane of Arborea and, if the Olympians were to be believed, the first deities to inhabit it. though the Titans preferred to refer to the plane as Tarterus. The name Othrys, as well as most of the names for the other layers of Carceri, were allegedly all derived from the special language of the greater titans. They were also the reason Othrys was referred to by some as '''Titan's Home''', since they were the layer's most famed inhabitants.

Of all the mountains of Othrys, the titans particularly congregated around [[Mount Othrys]]. The mountain hosted a great palace, a twisted echo of the edifices found on [[Olympus]], made of white [[marble]] that was brought with them down into Othrys. Over time the structure fell into disrepair, but the Titans could not leave Carceri to obtain marble to repair it with. Being a dilapidated, unrepairable echo of what the Titans once had on Olympus,{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|26}} the structure caused them both great frustration and pain, serving as a constant reminder of their lost glory.

A few greater titans managed to avoid imprisonment and still lived on the plane of Arborea, dwelling within its hinterlands. These titans were either nursing their grudges against Olympians or were completely oblivious as to most of the greater titans having been imprisoned.

Notable Members.Progeny & Servants:
All of the Titans came to birth [[lesser deity|lesser deities]] known as the [[lesser titan]]s. Some of them were loyal to their parents and became trapped in Carceri alongside them, where many of them became [[proxies]]. Others sided against them with the Olympians and were allowed to stay on Arborea.

Though the Titans were trapped in Carceri, they did have some agents and proxies. These were used to spy on and torment their enemies on the plane of Arborea.

document_data.Worshipers: Though the greater titans didn't require the worship of mortals to remain strong and the Olympians discouraged mortals from showing them reverence, this didn't stop some from worshiping them. The Titans didn't do anything to discourage reverence, though they somewhat feared retribution from the Olympians every time mortals called out their names.
document_data.Rumors & Legends: Some believed that the titans personified the building blocks of the Prime Material and that their continued existence was what kept the Prime functioning.

History.History with Toril: In the month of [[Hammer (month)|Hammer]], in the {{YearlinkName|1373}},{{LCRB}} a group of [[adventurer]]s from [[Ravens Bluff]] found themselves transported to the plane of Tarterus after defending the [[githzerai]] fortress of [[Tah'Darr]] from a [[tanar'ri]] incursion. At the urgings of the fallen [[paladin]] [[Elendil]], the adventurers sought out Mount Othrys and Cronus for a way back to their Prime Material world of [[Toril]].{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|9-10}} When they first entered the crumbling palace they were greeted by a {{SI|50|ft}} tall marble pillar, with a column of twenty [[spear]]s jammed down one crack, each impaled with the severed head of a man. They were then approached by the titan responsible, [[Chiron]], who demanded tribute from them in exchange for an audience with his father.{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|15}} Eventually the group made their way to Cronus, deep into some kind of [[Cosmic Game]] with the [[marilith]] [[Cucathne]], the latter of whom was entertaining the Titan with the game in hopes of negotiating the use of Othrys as a tanar'ri staging ground against Tah'Darr.{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|17,32}} Cronus was unwilling to answer any questions that the mortals posed, but offered to gate them home if they would fight as part of his forces in the game.{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|16}}
